snippet: To The Living Section:   I would like to clarify the quotation from me in your piece headlined "Bodies Go Public: It's Men's Turn Now" on Oct. 31. I am quoted as saying, "Taboos preserve the sense of special mystery of one gender as opposed to ano...
lead_paragraph: To The Living Section: I would like to clarify the quotation from me in your piece headlined "Bodies Go Public: It's Men's Turn Now" on Oct. 31. I am quoted as saying, "Taboos preserve the sense of special mystery of one gender as opposed to another" and thus "contribute to equality." Public displays and open discussion of male or female sexuality contribute to equality only if men and women participate equally. Formerly, displays of the female form underscored that men had the distinct power to look while women were looked upon, thus contributing to inequality . The new trend toward the unveiling of men's bodies means that both men and women are eqally open (or closed) to each other. This is why (as the next sentence properly says) the breakdown of taboos against display of the male body speaks to equality between the sexes. TODD GITLIN Professor of Sociology University of California Berkeley, Calif.

headline.main: Taboos and Sexuality

snippet: Pope John Paul II called today for equality between male and female workers, but said women who dedicated themselves to their families played an ''irreplaceable role'' and should not suffer discrimination.   ''The problem of juridical equality bet...
lead_paragraph: Pope John Paul II called today for equality between male and female workers, but said women who dedicated themselves to their families played an ''irreplaceable role'' and should not suffer discrimination. ''The problem of juridical equality between men and women workers should be resolved with a social legislation that recognizes the equality of men workers with women workers,'' the Pope told 30,000 people gathered in St. Peter's Square for his weekly blessing.

headline.main: Pope Calls for Equality Of Workers of Both Sexes

snippet: Hall's article was insightful and thorough. However, his conclusion -- that this trend ''seems to herald a dubious, regressive form of equality'' -- struck me as off the mark. Rather, I would argue that this obsession continues a tradition of male...
lead_paragraph: Hall's article was insightful and thorough. However, his conclusion -- that this trend ''seems to herald a dubious, regressive form of equality'' -- struck me as off the mark. Rather, I would argue that this obsession continues a tradition of male dominance. It seems to me that bodily socialization disempowers young women both literally and figuratively while empowering (at least some) adolescent boys to behaviors ranging from harassment to murder. Might it be that as women chip away at academic, professional and athletic terrain that was once exclusively male, men are feeling the need to assert their dominance in the bluntest and most obvious ways, and in the only area in which women truly cannot compete as equals? Tamara R. Dukes Sacramento, Calif.
abstract: Tamara R Dukes letter on Stephen S Hall's August 22 article holds boys' obsession with self image continues tradition of male dominance (S)

snippet: It is true that there are real problems between the sexes that need correction: equality and opportunity in employment; the maintenance of a woman's right of choice; the reduction of sexual harassment, rape, etc. But this silliness of stirring up ...
lead_paragraph: It is true that there are real problems between the sexes that need correction: equality and opportunity in employment; the maintenance of a woman's right of choice; the reduction of sexual harassment, rape, etc. But this silliness of stirring up gender differences where none should exist, making the female a symbol while the male is a cipher, is ridiculous. It must stop. Just Do It. Just Say No. Hey -- just get dressed. L. S. WINDHAM Austin, Tex.

lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re Maureen Dowd's April 24 column about Karen Hughes leaving her job in the White House: Women's rights is not about ''having it all,'' simply because no one has it all. Men for years have been making the sacrifices regarding family and career. When a professional is faced with a demanding job, there is going to be some sacrifice for the employee, male or female, professionally or personally.

lead_paragraph: There is a woman on the British throne and a woman at the head of the British Government, but to Michael English, a member of the British House of Commons, Queen Elizabeth and Margaret Thatcher aren't enough to assure equality of the sexes in Britain. headline.main: Briton Wants to Redraw the Line of Succession

snippet: To say that you do not object to sexism is different from saying that sexism does not exist. The Hechingers obviously do not object to the sexism on "Sesame Street." As an active feminist, I find it particularly unfortunate that male backlash shou...
lead_paragraph: To say that you do not object to sexism is different from saying that sexism does not exist. The Hechingers obviously do not object to the sexism on "Sesame Street." As an active feminist, I find it particularly unfortunate that male backlash should come from people as obviously literate as the Hechingers.

headline.main: " MALE BACKLASH"?

snippet: Francke calls herself a feminist and yet she insinuates that women, but not men, should be exempt from fighting and dying in war. She writes of her "uneasiness at women in their modern military roles" and of "values gone entirely awry." "I feel," ...
lead_paragraph: Francke calls herself a feminist and yet she insinuates that women, but not men, should be exempt from fighting and dying in war. She writes of her "uneasiness at women in their modern military roles" and of "values gone entirely awry." "I feel," she says, "that women and men should share equally in the burdens and the opportunities of citizenship. But the new military seems to have stretched equality to the breaking point." Unless we believe that the lives of women are worth more than the lives of men, or that women are incapable of performing some military duties -- and what true feminist believes that? -- what possible moral or intellectual justification could there be for exempting women from military service? "It hadn't seemed fair," Francke reflects, that her daughters were "chattering on about their hopes for interesting jobs after graduation" while their male friends were worrying about the possibility of a military draft. I've got news for her: it's not fair.

headline.main: REQUIEM FOR A SOLDIER

snippet: To the Sports Editor:      In their letters to the editor on Sunday, March 25, both Thomas P. McDonnell and Steven Goldberg responded to Donna de Varona's argument for women's equality in athletics (Women's Fight for Sports Equality Begins Again,'...
lead_paragraph: To the Sports Editor: In their letters to the editor on Sunday, March 25, both Thomas P. McDonnell and Steven Goldberg responded to Donna de Varona's argument for women's equality in athletics (Women's Fight for Sports Equality Begins Again,'' March 18) with a dangerously mistaken assumption: That performance determines whether women athletes should be treated fairly. Both argue that the Supreme Court's recent decision in the Grove City case, which weakens Title IX and, in essence, allows colleges to discriminate on the basis of sex, is justified because women athletes generally cannot beat their male counterparts.

headline.main: ; Don't Fund Women On Performance

snippet: To the Editor:   Quick to seize defeat from the jaws of victory, Ruth Rosen ("What Feminist Victory in the Court?", Op-Ed, April 1) assails the Supreme Court for reaffirming women's right to equality in the workplace in United Auto Workers v. John...
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Quick to seize defeat from the jaws of victory, Ruth Rosen ("What Feminist Victory in the Court?", Op-Ed, April 1) assails the Supreme Court for reaffirming women's right to equality in the workplace in United Auto Workers v. Johnson, a case involving battery manufacture. Ms. Rosen deplores the "impoverishment of the language of individual rights" and the "skewed" framework created by Title VII of the 1964 Civil Rights Act, which prohibits employment discrimination. She suggests the "inadequacy of liberal feminism" is to blame for hazardous workplaces. This analysis misapprehends the legal system and the facts of this case. The Court was asked to decide only whether barring fertile women from exposure to the lead in batteries, a hazard to fetal health, was impermissible sex discrimination. It was filed as a sex discrimination case because that was the strongest, if not only, legal claim available. It was not filed as an occupational safety and health case because workers cannot sue to enforce Federal occupational safety and health law.

headline.main: No Worker Should Face Unacceptable Choices

snippet: EQUALITY under the hoop, on the gridiron and around the diamond - that's the theme of a half-hour ''Currents'' documentary called ''Settling the Score,'' tonight at 8:30 on WNET/ Channel 13. Much of its information should come as news to those who...
lead_paragraph: EQUALITY under the hoop, on the gridiron and around the diamond - that's the theme of a half-hour ''Currents'' documentary called ''Settling the Score,'' tonight at 8:30 on WNET/ Channel 13. Much of its information should come as news to those who watch sports on television. The women on the program maintain that the stations and networks, major purveyors of the fame that leads to fortune, neglect serious female athletes. And it's true enough that, as John Dryden once put it in the quill-pen days, ''these athletic brutes whom undeservedly we call heroes'' (he meant, of course, the big boys in knickers who earn more than poets) do get a great deal of attention.

headline.main: DOCUMENTARY ON WOMEN IN SPORTS

snippet: To the Sports Editor: I read with interest Dave Anderson's column (The New York Times, May 10) ''Original Carl Hubbellito.''   In my book, ''The Meal Ticket'' was one of the greatest, along with Walter Johnson and Christy Matthewson.  Anderson wri...
lead_paragraph: To the Sports Editor: I read with interest Dave Anderson's column (The New York Times, May 10) ''Original Carl Hubbellito.'' In my book, ''The Meal Ticket'' was one of the greatest, along with Walter Johnson and Christy Matthewson. Anderson writes about Carl's ''most memorable performance,'' in striking out Ruth, Gehrig, Foxx, Simmons and Cronin in a row. However, it is my opinion that his greatest performance was the 18-inning shutout he pitched in the Polo Grounds on July 2, 1933. In lasting the entire game and winning in the 18th by a score of 1-0 against the St. Louis Cardinals, he allowed only six hits and did not walk a single batter in a game that lasted four hours. What a pitching performance. It was the greatest.

headline.main: DELIGHTFUL HUBBELL, 'THE MEAL TICKET'

snippet: Last August an administrative law judge in New Jersey ruled that a 15-year-old girl named Elizabeth Balsley had a constitutional right to play high school football. She joined the North Hunterdon High team, if only as a bench-warmer. But if she is...
lead_paragraph: Last August an administrative law judge in New Jersey ruled that a 15-year-old girl named Elizabeth Balsley had a constitutional right to play high school football. She joined the North Hunterdon High team, if only as a bench-warmer. But if she isn't much of a football player, other girls might be - and now can be, thanks to her.

snippet: To the Editor:    As a former executive who is now a full-time mom, I read Judith Shulevitz's review of Judith Warner's book ''Perfect Madness: Motherhood in the Age of Anxiety'' (Feb. 20) with interest -- and, in the end, with disappointment that...
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: As a former executive who is now a full-time mom, I read Judith Shulevitz's review of Judith Warner's book ''Perfect Madness: Motherhood in the Age of Anxiety'' (Feb. 20) with interest -- and, in the end, with disappointment that neither of them addresses what seems like a dangerous oversight in our (women's) quest for equality: we need wives. The two most successful career women I know are both married to men who stay home with their children. Is this too revolutionary an arrangement for us? Why do most women, even those who earn salaries in the top 5 percent, still hope to find a mate who earns more? As long as we hold onto the male ''provider'' role as an ideal, we will have a tough time finding equality anywhere. I know several men whose real dream would be to stay home and raise children but are afraid to admit it because it is such a societal taboo. Aren't these the men that future female lawyers, doctors and math professors should be seeking out? Alicia Vance South Orange, N.J.
abstract: Alicia Vance letter comments on Judith Shulevitz Feb 20 review of book Perfect Madness: Motherhood in the Age of Anxiety by Judith Warner

headline.main: 'Perfect Madness'

snippet: The head of the U.N. agency promoting equality for women is lamenting that a girl born today will be an 81-year-old grandmother before she has the same chance as a man to be CEO of a company — and she will have to wait until she's 50-years-o...
lead_paragraph: The head of the U.N. agency promoting equality for women is lamenting that a girl born today will be an 81-year-old grandmother before she has the same chance as a man to be CEO of a company — and she will have to wait until she's 50-years-old to have an equal chance to lead a country.
